sen.j: 手古舞(てこまい)は、祭りに於いて、山車や御輿を先導する舞。
sen.e: Tekomai is a dance performed to lead floats or omikoshi (portable shrine) in a festa.
Tekomai is a dance performed to lead floats or omikoshi (portable shrine) in a festival.
Tekomai is a dance performed to lead floats or omikoshi (portable shrine) in a festival.

sen.j: 華やかな衣装を着た厚化粧の女性が舞う。
sen.e: The dancers wear flamboyant costumes and thick makeup to dance.
It is performed by women wearing flamboyant costumes and thick makeup.
It is performed by women wearing flamboyant costumes and thick makeup.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 江戸中期頃、芸者が山車を先導する為、男性風の扮装で登場したのが始まり。
sen.e: The Tekomai started in the middle Edo period when a geisha (Japanese professional female entertainer at a drinking party) who was dressed up as a man appeared to lead a float.
The Tekomai started in the middle Edo period when geisha dressed as men turned up to lead a float.
sen.cmt: Grammar- removed definition of "geisha". I think this is a well enough known word
sen.e: The Tekomai started in the middle Edo period when geisha dressed as men turned up to lead a float.

sen.j: 現代では花街が断絶した地域においては、地域の若い女性が扮する場合が多く、又、小中学生以下の少女(稀に少年)が扮する場合も多い。
sen.e: Nowadays, in regions where hanamachi (fleshpots) disappeared, local young women are usually dressed up as a man or pre-school girls sometimes do (rarely, small boys).
Nowadays, in regions where the geisha quarter has disappeared, young women, or sometimes pre-school girls (and rarely, small boys), dress up as men.
Nowadays, in regions where the geisha quarter has disappeared, young women, or sometimes pre-school girls (and rarely, small boys), dress up as men.

sen.j: 扮装
sen.e: Costumes
Costumes
Costumes

sen.j: 衣装は、緋色で、派手な刺繍をした襦袢の上に、やや地味な着物(小袖ではなく、広袖の場合が多い)を、片肌脱ぎで着用、たっつけと呼ばれるズボン型の袴を着用、花笠(花笠まつりと同じ)を背中に付ける。
sen.e: The costumes are a scarlet and colorful embroidered juban (underwear), slightly somber kimono (wide-sleeved, not short-sleeved), a pants-type hakama called Tattsuke (tapered hakama pants) and a hanagasa (bamboo hat decorated with artificial flowers (the same used for Hanagasa Festival), and the Tekomai dancers first wear the juban, the kimono without putting an arm through one sleeve of the kimono, the hakama, and the hanagasa on their back.

The costumes are a scarlet and colorfully embroidered juban (underwear), slightly somber kimono (wide-sleeved, not short-sleeved), a pants-type hakama called Tattsuke and a bamboo hanagasa hat decorated with artificial flowers (the same as is used for the Hanagasa Festival), and the Tekomai dancers first put on the juban, the kimono without putting an arm through one sleeve of the kimono, the hakama, and the hanagasa on their back.
sen.cmt: GrammarMerged explanation of hanagasa into man body of sentence
sen.e: The costumes are a scarlet and colorfully embroidered juban (underwear), slightly somber kimono (wide-sleeved, not short-sleeved), a pants-type hakama called Tattsuke and a bamboo hanagasa hat decorated with artificial flowers (the same as is used for the Hanagasa Festival), and the Tekomai dancers first put on the juban, the kimono without putting an arm through one sleeve of the kimono, the hakama, and the hanagasa on their back.

sen.j: 化粧は歌舞伎舞踊と、ほぼ同じ舞台化粧が原則だが、自毛で結った場合や少女の場合は大人のフォーマルや、民謡舞踊、大衆演劇と同様の厚化粧、バレエと同様な洋風の厚化粧、と、結構様々である。
sen.e: The dancers basically apply stage makeup like Kabuki Buyo dancers, and also, there is a variety of makeup, like formal/complete adult-style makeup in case of a hairdo made with dancer's own hair and young girls and thick makeup like Minyo Buyo (local folk song) dancers or actresses in Taishu Engeki (popular stage/drama.)
sen.cmt: 日本語が分かりにくいです。
sen.e: The dancers usually apply Kabuki-style stage makeup, but if the dancers are not wearing a wig or are young girls, they apply formal style makeup, with other styles including those similar to folk dancers, travelling performers and ballerinas.

The dancers usually apply Kabuki-style stage makeup, but if the dancers are not wearing a wig or are young girls, they apply formal style makeup, with other styles including those similar to folk dancers, travelling performers and ballerinas.
sen.cmt: 訳者コメントに「日本語がわかりにくい」とありますが、「自毛で結った場合や少女の場合」は次の文中にもあり、それがこの文に混ざっているのだと思います。

sen.j: 髪型は、刷毛先(銀杏髷)と呼ばれる、男性風の日本髪の鬘を被るのが原則だが、自毛で結った場合や少女の場合は男性風に限らず、結綿、桃割れ、稚児髷といった、少女風の髪型になる場合も多い。
sen.e: The dancers principally wear a wig of manlike Japanese-style hairdo called brush tip (ichomage (hairstyle like a leaf of the sacred gingko tree)), but in case of hairdo made with a dancer's own hair or a young girl dancer, girl-like hairstyles such as yuiwata (traditional hairstyle worn by unmarried women), momoware (split peach) and chigomage (with a forelock symbolizing youth) are often seen as well as man-style hairdos.

The dancers generally wear a ichomage-style wig, (ichomage is a ginko leaf-shaped men's hairstyle, usually seen these days on sumo wrestlers) but if the dancer is not wearing a wig or is a young girl, more feminine hairstyles such as yuiwata (traditional hairstyle worn by unmarried women), momoware (literally split peach) and chigomage (with a forelock symbolizing youth) are often seen as well.
sen.cmt: Revised explanation of ichomageRevised for clarity
sen.e: The dancers generally wear a ichomage-style wig, (ichomage is a ginko leaf-shaped men's hairstyle, usually seen these days on sumo wrestlers) but if the dancer is not wearing a wig or is a young girl, more feminine hairstyles such as yuiwata (traditional hairstyle worn by unmarried women), momoware (literally split peach) and chigomage (with a forelock symbolizing youth) are often seen as well.

sen.j: 栃木県内では日本髪を結わずに手拭を姉さん被りにする場合もある。
sen.e: In Tochigi Prefecture, the dancers occasionally cover their heads with a Tenugui towel in anesan kaburi (women used to cover their heads with a Tenugui towel to keep their head clean long time ago) rather than Japanese coiffure.

In Tochigi Prefecture, the dancers occasionally wear "anesan kaburi", where a tenugui towel covers the hair (in the past, women used to cover their hair with a Tenugui towel to keep it clean) rather than a Japanese hairstyle.

In Tochigi Prefecture, the dancers occasionally wear "anesan kaburi", where a tenugui towel covers the hair (in the past, women used to cover their hair with a Tenugui towel to keep it clean) rather than a Japanese hairstyle.

sen.j: 持ち物は、右手に金棒(上に鉄製の輪が4～6個付く鉄製の棒)、左手に自分の名前が書かれた提灯を持ち、木遣りを歌いながら行進する。
sen.e: The dancers carry an iron club (4-6 iron rings attached at the top of the club) in their right hand and a Chochin (Japanese paper lantern) with the dancer's name written on it in their left hand and march singing Kiyari (songs sung by firemen.)

The dancers carry an iron club with 4-6 iron rings attached to the top in their right hand and a Chochin (Japanese paper lantern) with the dancer's name written on it in their left hand and march singing Kiyari (songs sung by firemen.)

The dancers carry an iron club with 4-6 iron rings attached to the top in their right hand and a Chochin (Japanese paper lantern) with the dancer's name written on it in their left hand and march singing Kiyari (songs sung by firemen.)
